posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
All the talk about Minsc lately made me dig up an old post on the challenges of building Minsc for NWN from the old Bioware forum, that I still have on my hard drive.
He appeared both in BG1 and BG2 but with slightly different builds. Translating his stats and skills from 2nd to 3rd ed is another challenge.
He’s male and human – that’s the easy part.
In BG 1 he’s neutral good and in BG 2 he’s chaotic good. In my opinion he is definitely CG!

His stats in BG 1 are STR 18/93 DEX 15 CON 15 INT 8 WIS 6 CHA9. In BG 2 the DEX and CON are increased to 16.
These are 2.ed stats and they cannot be translated directly to 3.ed rules, NWN and the point buy system. The stat bonuses work differently in 2. and 3. ed. and you can’t get 18,15,15,8,6,9 with 30 points. Anyway I see him as a STR based “fighter type”, primarily ranger with low mental stats.
In BG 1 his weapon proficiencies are Large sword, Longbow and Axe. In BG 2 his proficiencies are Two handed sword, Longbow, Axe, Mace and Two weapon fighting.
Minsc has no ranger spells, or any other magic, so wisdom should be below 10 and no UMD spellcasting.
He had "charm animal" as a special ability. Perhaps animal empathy covers that.
2nd ed. rangers had stealth as a class skill. But somehow I don't see Minsc as the "silent type" sneaking about.
Minsc had the rage ability "berserk". His rage seemed somehow to be linked to his pet, Boo, the feracious miniature, giant space hamster. I don't know how to apply that, but barbarian will give the rage ability.
Big rangers don't need big animal companions, and Minsc kept his underneath his shirt, or somewhere out of sight... But if you want to display the animal, the closest you get is the dire rat, the only rodent companion - unless sombody knows a "hamster hak" out there.
His favored enemies in BG were gnolls and vampires. That should easily be covered with the abundant amount of FEs in NWN.
Minsc was on a mission to protect Dynaheir when we first met him. Later she went missing again and Jaheira tried to influence him, always behaving like everybody's big sister. Maybe she even succeeded in recruiting him to her organization - or maybe not. I wonder what NWN damsel he would protect; Linu, Aribeth, Dorna or Sharwyn, but most probably not Nathyrra.

Edit: I am tempted to give him Iron will and maybe even epic will just to reflect his stubbornness.

Now, before I post anything that resembles a build, I want your feedback and ideas that can be taken into a Minsc build.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Minsc is a character that most people would want in a party or even as a friend. What's not to like about him? He is strong in a fight and loyal to his friends, plus he is not a meddler of any kind. I think he is the equivalent of "Gimli son of Gloin" in Baldur's Gate saga. Now, when it comes to his NWN incarnation we need to think not only what his obvious traits are but also what was intended by his creators. I will list some examples as to what i am talking about below.

a) Minsc traditional weapon was the Halberd. This is the weapon that comes with in BG1. But if we look in BG2 he has a "destined" for him, two-handed sword that talks and a whole bunch of dialog written for that purpose, named "Lilarcor". I would pick one or the other doesn't really matter and although he could dual-wield i think the stereotype of the big-and-strong guy goes better with a two-handed weapon, i would rate slightly higher the Greatsword for NWN purposes.

b) Minsc despite his head wound that had the side-effrect to reduce his wisdom to below average levels, could quite efficiently cast ranger spells (or divine spells from the appropriate spheres for DnD 2nd Ed), we can see that in BG2, and he never dropped from Ranger status despite his illegal mental scores (you would need 13 wisdon to be a Ranger in 2nd Ed). In fact Minsc in the "Throne Of Bhaal" expansion is considered to be one of the best tanks in the game for this synergy: (Armour Of  Faith, Hardiness, Defender Of Eastheaven). That offered an 80-85% of total physical Dmg. Reduction and key to that combo was his divine spell, "Armour Of Faith". To me, he needs full Ranger spells for NWN purposes.

Minsc's alignment is the very definition of CG if you ask me. Some 2nd Ed. DnD adventures had CONAN be CG also, but i think he is more of a CN type than anything else. Now, Minsc's class is a tougher choice. He is definitely a Ranger we have established that, and we obviously must include Barbarian to represent his uncontrollable (and often fatal, sigh) rages.. But what about (if any) his third class? Frrom what we know about basic character building we ideally need a third class with "tumble" as a class skill if we are about to make him a "good-playable character", or else the lack of AC will kill him fast. Personally, i am in favour of a few levels of Bard in there. Both Rogue and Bard could work fine but i think that Bard's ability to have maximum ranks in spellcraft too, better represents the "Barbarian's Superstition" and thus resistance to spells-weavers. Another debate could be made for the selection or not of "Devastating Critical" in this build. This should be the natural evvolution for a really strong guy but i think that the only person that really justifies that feat is "Sarevok" with his "deathbringer assaut" special ability. For all the others-and-Minsc, i would say a big strength score plus the Ranger's FE's bonusses are more than enough for the job.

I will stop here and see what you will do with these parameters in mind Mick, and i am more than happy to debate each point with you.

I found that the divine wrath of CoT was what looked most like the offensive spin, especially if you add ki damage and the crits from weapon master. The spell war cry also adds something that resemles offensive spin. Defensive spin is covered by expertise, song AC, tumble and the concealment from the displacement or improved invisivility spell.
CoT is there only for game mechanical reasons, I dont see Haer' Dalis as a divine character at all. I tried to find room for some tiefling traits as well. Bluff and taunt should reflect parts of his personality. Replace bluff with spellcraft or UMD if you want more of a power-build. I tried to find place for the standard tiefling "resist energy fire" before i realized that Haer' dalis didn't have any resistances in BG2.
He should buff dex with cat's and wear a chain-shirt for armor.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Mick, thou art a diamond - couldn't wish for a better Xmas prezzie!

If I may make a couple of contributions to the Minsc-build conversation, they would be:

i) Boo isn't really an issue, as he is never seen in BG1 or 2 outside Minsc's 'doll' (much to my disappointment, but you can't have everything), and I'm positive he would take no other animal companion

ii) I suspect Minsc's NG status in BG1 is down to his affinity with nature and, thereby, druids, who in BG1 have to play as true neutral, while Dynaheir, as his witch is LG, hence the 'good'. His CG conversion is (aside from his personality), I am sure, is down to the too many blows to the head and somehow equating his childlike (not childish) joy of life to a 'chaotic' characterization.

iii) The prime purpose of Minsc's D'Jema (spelling?) was to bring him membership of the berserker lodge in Rasheman, which he would accomplish by his secondary purpose, to accompany and keep safe Dynaheir (hence his buggering off if you remove Dynaheir from the party. Hate to say it, but I have sacrificed her several times in the Bandit Camp in BG1 - had her cast fireball on entering the main camp tent while alone. Of course, I could just have parked in a house in Beregost/Naskel, but an heroic death seemed more fitting.). If you get the final cut-scenes at the end of BG2 ToB, you are told that he achieved his prime goal, and, indeed, established his own Berserker lodge. So he definitely needs Barbarian in NwN, in the absence of Berserker.

iv) I find it interesting that in BG2, the Dynaheir-less Minsc adopts Aerie the faerie - sorry, Avariel - as his new witch, and also clearly adores Keldorn's nature - both of whom are LG, like Dynaheir was. I don't know if that tells us anything, but...

v) While it is true that Minsc has access to all the available Ranger spells in BG, my 'feel' of the character is that they come through his joy in nature, rather than clerical discipline, as Bard would probably be a grand addition to a build for him. However - and I'm afraid I'm dismissing classic Rogue, there's absolutely nothing to indicate he would possess any of the Rogue's traits - I find I'm running out of room - he's a Ranger, he's a Fighter (full-plate and packing steel), he's a Barbarian (possibly mergeable), he's a Bard, he's a Harper Scout??!! In a way, it's a shame he can't be a Dwarven Defender, because they embody much of Minsc's 'come and have a go' trait!

vi) On a personal level, unless I'm playing a Fighter or Paladin in BG2, I always have Minsc dual-wielding the Crom Faeyr (spelling?) and Mace of Disruption/Flail of Ages/ that axe that "lops off heads like nobody's business", so I'm delighted Mick's build keeps the dual-wield option open. As a btw, I've never encountered Minsc with a halberd - every time I first meet him in Nashkel he has a 2-handed sword, and competences that match it.

Don't know if any of that helps, I just got excited! Great build looking forward to having a go with it!

As to other BG characters: I would see Valygar as katana-wielding ranger and (albeit reluctant) arcane archer, except we'd have to elf him, hmmm...Oh, yes, that could be a Kivan/Valygar mix-up. I mention it as a possibility only because in BG2 (as in NwN, as far as I can see), ranged weapons are of very limited use - and none at all against 'big bosses' - so Kivan would need some melee skills, which Valygar has. Worth a thought, maybe?

Others that may be of interest include Coran, Imoen (I always dual-class her to mage in BG1, hence my blowing up of Dynaheir) and, especially, Viconia. Oooh, I've come over all unnecessary!

a) Simply by taking the last three levels of CoT in Epic, at timed intervals (let's say at 25th, 33rd and 40th) you can save the skill points for "Spot" and take them when Mazzy reach a CoT level. Don't take it at Fighter levels, only at CoT ones. It's the same "trick" we do with many other skills including "Tumble" or "UMD" and so on... In othr words, normally a Fighter wouldn't have a 43 Spot because the skill is a cross-class (21 ranks max) skill for him, but with CoT levels in Epic, Mazzy can have 43 Spot by 40th level easily.

b) The "Stacking" of Fighter and CoT pre-epic will produce better saves as well. That is because if you look  CoT at Wiki, you will see that he has Two) good base saves, not One. A good base save is always +12 (base value. before attributes factored in), a poor base save is always +6. So, what you did by mixing them before Epic levels is that you pumped the overall saving throws of your build even more, that's before the additional +5 to all saving throws Mazzy will have from her 10 CoT levels! To give you a visual example of how the correct multi-class (as in this case) improves the saves,

Fighter Saving Throws(At level 10): Fort: +7/ Reflex: +3/ Will: +3
CoT Saving Thows(At level 10):       Fort: +7/ Reflex: +7/ Will: +3

Fighter (Single-Class) Saving Thows(At level 20):       Fort: +12/ Reflex: +6/  Will: +6
Fighter/CoT (Multi-Class) Saving Throws(At level 20): Fort: +14/ Reflex: +10/ Will: +6 (Again, this is before the +5 universal bonus of CoT to all saving throws)

c) There are some skills that we try to have them in any build that we make. These skills are Discipline, Tumble and Spellcraft.

Discipline is self-explanatory, if you don't have it then any enemy can knock-you-down and you will never get up till you die. In O.C this might not be the case but believe me, in almost everywhere else is, and there aren't always boots that will make your character immune to knockdown.
Tumble works in (unmodified by your attributes) brackets of 5 ranks (5, 10, 15 e.t.c). In every such step we get an unconditional +1 AC for our character. Because the AC of our character is very important, we always take this skill even if it is not a "Class Skill" for our character.
Spellcraft works in (modified by your attributes) brackets of 5 ranks (5, 10, 15 e.t.c). In every such step we get an uncoditional +1 to all saving throws Vs spells. Again, this is a very important skill for all characters and thus it's always taken.

Now let's go back to Mazzy. As a Fighter she takes 2 skill points/level and the same is true when she levels as a CoT, again 2 skill points/level. You see "Fighter Classes" do not get a lot of skill points :/ Thankfully we have 14 Intelligence (+2 modifier) so she will have 4 skill points/level. And look, we also have 4 skill that we want them maxed, be it cross-class or-not. Discipline, Tumble, Spellcraft and Spot. See, how you put all those extra skill points into their place now? :-)

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This is not poop. You are definitely on the right track. But there are many things you can do to improve the build.
The starting stats are all right.  The level spread is fine. Both can be different, but what you have will work fine.
You can get more AB, you can get better AC, you can improve the saves, get epic dodge earlier and you can get more skillpoints. That is a matter of refining the build.
The only thing I spot that is completely wrong is that you try to take defensive roll on a general feat. You have to take it as a bonus feat at rogue lvl 10 or 13. Epic dodge on the other hand, can be taken as a general feat once you meet the prereqs.

How to improve the number of skillpoints: Take rogue at level 1 and earn 18 skillpoints. If you start with rogue you get 10 x 4 skillpoints at level 1. If you start with fighter you only get 16 skilpoints at level 1. Later the rogue level will give you 10 skillpoints and the fighter level 4 skillpoints. (40 + 4) - (16 + 10) = 18.

What you can do to improve the AB and AC:
Rogue pre epic gives a hit to AB. Rogue level 1, level 5, level 9, level 13 and level 17 cost 1 AB each. If you only take 4 rogue levels pre epic and avoid rogue 5 that early, you gain 1 AB. (You would gain one more AB if you waited with rogue until level 21, but I will not advice that.)
You take several pre epic feats after lvl 20. If you are more strict with what pre epic feats to take, you free up epic feats for great dex and can improve both AB and AC. You also choose to take 2 great strength feats. If you rather take 2 great dex feats, you will improve AB and AC by 1.

How to improve the saves: Replace as many fighter levels as you can with CoT pre epic. CoT pre epic has both reflex and fortitude as primary saves while fighter only has fortitude. Levelling will also be smoother since you get the saves bonus from sacred defence earlier.

How to get epic dodge earlier: The earliest you can get epic dodge is at level 27. If you only take 4 levels of rogue pre epic, you can get there by level 30. If you want some CoT/fighter levels for epic bonus combat-feats in early epic levels, you can still get epic dodge by level 33. Don't delay epic dodge. Save the last rogue level for a skill-dump at level 37-39.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
First of all, congrats for your first real build Stagmeister!

And although i would prefer if you have made a dual-class version of Mazzy first (FTR 30/ COT 10) so we could make the transition to the full build easier for you, you seized the initiative and delivered a good combo by yourself. As Mick said previously, it's far from being a bad build and what's more your class split seems good enough. Alriight, now let's begin with the "refinement" of your build, aye?

a) First thing, we need to do is to make sure the build is legal 1.69 in Neverwinter Nights, so you will have to replace/change the "Great Dexterity" feats from the bonus epic feats a Fighter can take. Similarly, in your first version of Mazzy, you cannot take "Great Strength" as a bonus epic Fighter feat, in fact "Great Strength" can only be taken in epic general feat levels (21, 24, 27, 30, 33, 36, 39) as no class has it in it's bonus feat list. You might also want to change "Toughness" from your 16th level slot, and put it on a general feat level (1, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18) as it is no CoT bonus feat (or any class for that matter). You can change positions with "Great Cleave" if you want.

b) Something very useful to know, is that you can take EWS in any weapon that you have already WS, in any CoT bonus feat level. Alone CoT cannot take even the simple WS but once he has it form the Fighter, he can take the Epic version just fine with his own bonus feats.

c) Your HP's are correct. Mazzy has exactly 464 HP's, a little anemic, eh but we will see what we can do later for that. Don't forget that she has...

d) Epic Dodge! That is a very, very nice feat to have! You could take it a bit earlier if you tried enough but we will fix thaat earlier, no big deal.

e) Your skill points are correct likewise, Mazzy has exactly 256 skill points, but do not forget that you must tell people where to put all those lovely skill points eh? Or else people will put them to "Lore" cause they don't like to go back to store to identify their items ;-)

f) An easy way to calculate the AB of your character is to look what Base Attack Bonus (BAB), they have at the first 20 levels of their life. Mazzy has all full BAB classes except four levels of Rogue (3/4 BAB) pre-epic. Those (3/4 BAB) classes work in clusters of  "Four", as Mick explained before. As long as you have only four levels pre-epic then you lose only (1 BAB) which is a small price to pay for the early playability Rogue brings to the table. So, keeping that in mind we have 19 BAB pre-epic aand then epic is  all the same for everyone. All classes gain +10 BAB more from the 20 epic levels. Thus Mazzy has 19+10= 29 BAB. Write that down to the BAB section of your paper, then let's do the AB math.

Total AB= BAB +(WF, EWF, EP) +(Attribute Modifier) => MAzzy's AB= 29 +4 +11 (If your Dexterity is correct, i will assume it is for now) => 44 AB. Again, you calculated correctly.

g) Your AC is 10 (Base) +2 (Armour Skin) +8 (Full Tumble Ranks) +11 (Dexterity Modifier) +2 (Large Shield, Halflings cannot use a Tower Shield) +1 (Halfling Size Bonus) => Mazzy's AC is 34, (Carefull, this is without Plate mail, as it will interfere with your Dexterity bonus, thus Lowering your total AC!)

h) Calculating your Saving Throws is easy as well (well, easy when you have done it before). For this you will need to consult the Wiki and look at what the individual bonuses are before epic, then add them together. Here, let's do that together for this time.

8 Lvl's of Fighter: 6/2/2 (Fort/Ref/Will)
8 Lvl's of CoT: 6/6/2 (Fort/Ref/Will)
4 Lvl's of Rogue: 1/4/1 (Fort/Ref/Will)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
(Ftr 8/ CoT 8/ RoG 4): 13/ 12/ 5 (Fort/Ref/Will) --> That's up to Lvl 20.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+10 To all Saving Throws: 23/ 22/ 15 (Fort/Ref/Will) --> That's for the 20 Epic Lvl's.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+2 Fort (CON)/ +11 Ref (DEX) -1 (Will): 25/ 33/ 14 (Fort/Ref/Will) --> That's for your Attributes.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+1 To all your Saving Throws for being a Hin. 26/ 34/ 15 (Fort/Ref/Will) --> Hin's have the "Lucky" Trait.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+2 (Will): 26/ 34/ 17 (Fort/Ref/Will) --> That's for your feat "Iron Will"
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+5 To all your Saving Throws: 31/ 39/ 22 (Fort/Ref/Will) --> That's for having 10 Lvl's of COT.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Great dex must be taken as a general feat with these classes. Epic dodge can be taken at a rogue bonus feat, but you don't have any more left, so you must use a general feat. As for skills:
The way you take discipline, maxing every time is how I do it too.
You do the same with spot, and that is fine as well.
You take spellcraft for the bonus to saves vs spells. With intelligence 14 you get a +2 bonus to spellcraft. You get +1 to the saves for every 5 modified ranks. So with 3 ranks plus the intelligence bonus your modified rank is 5 and you get +1 to saves vs spells. With 8 ranks your modified rank is 10 granting a +2 bonus to the saves etc. The max you can achieve alone when you cross class spellcraft is a +4 bonus to saves from 20 modified ranks with 18 ranks invested.  If you take 21 ranks like you do, you reach 23 modified ranks. You can still reach 25 for a +5 bonus if you raise intelligence by 4 (items/fox's) or wear items with a skill bonus.
The AC bonus you get from tumble is based on the ranks you take, not the modified ranks. If you take 5 ranks, you get a +1 AC bonus, if you take 10 you get +2 AC etc. With a class like rogue that has tumble as class skill, you can have 5 ranks at level 2, 10 ranks at level 7, 15 ranks at level 12, 20 ranks at level 17 etc. So if you take rogue at these levels you can max the tumble AC as early as possible. You should stop at 40 ranks, like you do. There is no reason to take it any further.

posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
I just have one question // If I can take 5 points of Tumble at level 2, does that hold true for Spot, Search and UMD as class-skills for Rogue? The underpinning question being: is it still ok for me to take Fighter at L1, then Rogue at L2, and still have this apply, or do I need Rogue at L1 as well? (The latter would knacker the build from level 1 for me, 'cause I'd miss the bonus feat there and couldn't make it up elsewhere.) If I can do Fighter at L1 and Rogue at L2 and attract those 'extra' 3 points for each of the skills, can I then hold them over for my final 'skills dump' at level 37? That might not be the most stylish way to use them, but I'm doing it all on paper, and my brain's beginning to bleed with all the maths!
 
You can save skillpoints for later skilldumps. At any levelup you can spend what skillpoints you have gained at that level and the ones you have saved from earlier. You decide how many of the available skillpoints you want to spend.
For class skills you can reach (characterlevel +3) ranks. At character creation (lvl 1) you can have 4 ranks in a class skill, at level 2 you can have 5 ranks etc.
The different classes have different sets of class skills, and that does have impact on when you want to take the classes in a multiclass-build. It becomes important to know your classes and what class skills they have.

Discipline is a class skill for fighter and CoT. You want to top discipline at fighter and CoT levels.
Spot is a class skill for CoT and rogue, and you want to put points in spot at rogue and CoT levels.
Spellcraft is a cross class skill for all your classes, so it doesn't matter what class you take when you put ranks in that skill. You spend 2 skillpoints for each cross class rank, and can have 2 ranks at level 1, 3 ranks at level 3, 4 ranks at level 5 etc.

Tumble is a class skill for rogue and you want to put points in tumble at rogue levels. If you take rogue at level 2, you can have 5 ranks in tumble, no matter what you took at level 1. Since tumble gives +1 AC every 5 ranks, it is popular to take rogue at level 2, 7, 12, 17 etc. to be able to get 5, 10, 15, 20 etc ranks as soon as possible.

UMD is a class skill for rogue and it cannot be cross-classed. UMD let you use class- race- and alignment-restricted items that you normally don't have access to. What items you can use improves with every 5 modified UMD ranks you get. UMD is modified by charisma, and your modifier is -1 since your charisma is only 8. Your build will need 6 ranks im UMD to get a modified rank of 5, and 11 ranks to get a modified rank of 10 etc. You will be able to get 6 ranks at level 3 and 11 ranks at level 8 if you take rogue at those levels. So if you want to get a high UMD as soon as possible, you take rogue at level 3, 8, 13, 18 etc.

I have given you reasons to take rogue at level1 and level 2, 7, 12, 17 etc, but also level 3, 8, 13, 18 etc. I have also told you why you don't want more than 4 rogue levels pre epic. That means that you have to make some choices and decide what you think is most important: Rogue at level 1 for max skillpoints, at level 2, 7, 12, 17 etc to max tumble AC asap or at level 3, 8, 13, 18 to max UMD asap.
Many of my builds have rogue at level 1, 7, 12, 17 etc, but sometimes I go 1, 8, 13, 18 etc.

Now, I have to stress that skill management is not everything, feats are also important. You have chosen a series of rogue levels during early epic levels to be able to get epic dodge at level 33. Your last rogue level should come at levl 37 or later depending on when you want your last rogue skill-dump.

I hope this helps answering your question(s).

Max, dual class was what humans could do, starting with one class and then jumping to another for the rest of their career, and retaining the abilities of the first class once the second class had more levels than the first. Multiclassing was what the other races could do, developing 2 or 3 classes simultaneously.
Aerie was a cleric/mage multiclass. The mage class worked like wizards do, filling slots with spells to remember, unlike sorcerer. Domains are extra powers that a Cleric has. Think of them as something additional to the normal Cleric powers. Each domain powers are different and a Cleric can select two of them. As an example, War Domain gives you the "Battle Mastery" ability that is usable once/ rest but also two new spells that normally Clerics do not have access to (cat's grace and aura of vitality). We usually select domains first and foremost for the additional spell choices that they add to the normal spell list. There are many wonderful things that domains can give to a standard cleric and a great way to customize them, Sun domain, for example, turns your Cleric into a bane for the undead and its powers are constant. You can see the different domain in the wiki,

http://nwn.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Cleric_domains

As for the Exp penalties, I say, if you can avoid them, then do so. Building with human is a great way to do that and yes, in your fantasy Viconia can be a human, no problem at all. Case in point, "my" Viconia in BG II never was a spell-slinger only, in fact she was in the thick of battle wielding Crom Fayer (gives her Titan's strength) and equipped with the best full plate armour she could find. CoS* stands for Champion of Shar.

Ha ha ha, alright Mick, I got your point.

To be fair & just, I will say what my approach was for that matter.

a) Form before items, meaning that his general style is way more important than his weapons and their interpretations throughout the different editions of D&D. In AD&D drow could dual-wield with no problems, in D&D 3rd. Edition there are penalties for that and two medium weapons will impose a -4/-4 penalty to his THAC0 even on the best of scenarios. Drizzt fought with grace, precision & speed and that must be maintained at all costs.

b) Functionality before prestige, meaning that when we all see a famous character from the novels we tend to over-estimate them in various ways. In the novels, all characters seem to be unbeatable and of the highest caliber, especially so in this category, we don't talk about modern-gritty fantasy like "Joe Abercrombie" here but heroic old-school one. Truth is that Drizzt was a great swordsman but he can be depicted without making use of the weapon-master class which is a modern concept anyway (Kensai from Oriental Adventures, excluded). Drizzt was adventuring in the wilds for almost all of his life, he was a follower of Mielikki and he taught directly from the great ranger Montollio (whose cloak we can find in BG II) . Thuss Drizzt, for me at least was a fighter and a ranger first & foremost & his time in the Underdark but also in the society of the drow warrants him to be part rogue as well. Well, the third can be debated but when I said earlier "functionality before prestige" I needed a way to make him (very) hard to hit & there is no better way for that than ED.

Concluding my thoughts we have his three classes, those are ranger/ fighter/ rogue. He is dexterity-based & his weapons are kukris (the only finessable slashing weapon that does not impose a huge penalty on his AB). He has Bane of Enemies & Epic weapon specialization to compensate for his lack of strength. Lastly, he has Epic Dodge & high dexterity in order to make him (very) hard to hit by his numerous opponents. With his UMD he can operate a wand of darkness while he can cast UV on himself to represent his innate drow abilities. He has a (real) animal companion, a black panther named Guenhwyvar that can distract & harass his enemies & lastly he has the parry skill that gets augmented by his natural high dexterity. All of these work in harmony in order to give us one of the deadliest warriors in the fictional world.
